results.title: Creating with shapes
results.creator_credit: Coronet Instructional Films and Dick Larson
results.brief_description: Objects in nature, man-made objects, children’s art, and famous paintings introduce the three basic shapes: rectangles, triangles and circles. After learning to observe shapes, we see children creating and arranging shapes to form original works of art.
results.description: Objects in nature, man-made objects, children’s art, and famous paintings introduce the three basic shapes: rectangles, triangles and circles. After learning to observe shapes, we see children creating and arranging shapes to form original works of art.

results.title: Creating with clay
results.brief_description: A teacher demonstrates wire and spiral wedging using nylon to string to divide clay. Students create spontaneously - pinch bowls, coil pot, slab draping and decorating, fist forms, texturing and string sculpture.
results.description: A teacher demonstrates wire and spiral wedging using nylon to string to divide clay. Students create spontaneously - pinch bowls, coil pot, slab draping and decorating, fist forms, texturing and string sculpture.

results.title: Creating with ceramics
results.creator_credit: Crystal, Dick Hoffman, Tom Hubbard and David Hubbard
results.brief_description: Provides an introduction to the techniques of clay gathering, mixing, wedging, throwing, glazing and firing by showing three potters creating three pieces, each of a different style.

results.title: Creating space
results.creator_credit: Angelo Stea, Gatineau and Peter Lauterman
results.brief_description: An Artist commune in Toronto for painters, weavers, sculptors, photographers and architects, operating on a co-operative basic with the artists sharing living space and sharing ideas. Narrated by Peggy Graham.

results.title: Creating an open discussion
results.creator_credit: Richard Murison, Barbara Dunning, Meredith D. Gall and Far West Laboratory for Educational Research and Development
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Discussing Controversial Issues”.
By providing topics for discussion teachers acting as moderators in separate classrooms show how a discussion can be productively carried out. The film clearly shows the jobs of both the moderator and the participants. Shows how to develop an open (non-threatening) situation in which meaningful discussions can take place.

results.title: Creating a homely atmosphere
results.creator_credit: Dept of Health, Richmond Implementation Unit, Tony Shaddock, Helen Edwards and Tim Abbott
results.brief_description: Designed to introduce the intellectual disability residential care worker to some simple ways of creating a homelike environment in the physical sense with furnishing and decor, how to create a desirable psychological atmosphere through community involvement and high quality staff-resident, staff-staff and resident-resident interactions, an interpretation of the term “normalisation” and how this principle might be applied in a residential setting and the recognition of the individual resident’s rights in what is their home. Accompanied by 32p. in-service training manual.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dept of Health, Richmond Implementation Unit, Tony Shaddock, Helen Edwards and Tim Abbott

results.title: Creating a dance (TEFC)
results.brief_description: The first part of the film traces stages in the creation of a demonstration of dance movement, examining the constituent parts and illustrating how the solutions to some of the associated problems were evolved. The second part presents the entire demonstration without comment. Dance direction and narration by Valerie Preston-Dunlop.

results.title: Creating
results.creator_credit: Peter Montagnon, Alasdair Clayre, Patrick Lui and Nigel Houghton
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “Heart of the Dragon”.
This program looks at the world of contemporary Chinese art, exploring the philosophic and historic influences that shape it. The way that Chinese artists pursue the essence of “reality” is examined as are the techniques which combine traditional values with unconventional materials to produce works that are resplendently Chinese.

results.title: Created equal
results.creator_credit: Michael Latham, Video Arts and Graham Massey
results.brief_description: Milton Friedman discusses freedom and equality, arguing that a society which maximises the scope for individual choice and action will be more successful at creating equal opportunities for all than a society which seeks to achieve quality through distribution of wealth.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Latham, Video Arts and Graham Massey
